titlestmt.titleproper: Register to the Archimandrite Amvrosii papers

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2014-04-25T14:02-0700

change.item: April 25, 2014: Copied biographical information from the Hoover website.

did.abstract: Correspondence, speeches and writings, and photographs, relating to the Russian Orthodox Church and to Russian émigré affairs.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives

prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Archimandrite Amvrosii (Konovalov) Papers, [Box no.], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 2008

altformavail.head: Alternative Forms of Material Available
altformavail.p: A portion of the collection is available on Microfilm

originalsloc.head: Location of Original Materials
originalsloc.p: Holy Trinity Orthodox Seminary, Jordanville, New York

chronitem.event: Born Victor Andreevich Konovalov, St. Petersburg, Russia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: This collection contains the papers of Viktor Andreevich Konovalov, a self-proclaimed missionary of Canada in emigration, and later a Russian Orthodox monk and abbot of the Pokrov Skete in Bluffton, Alberta, Canada. Konovalov's rich Correspondence includes letters to and from prominent hierarchs of the Russian diaspora, located throughout the world, and provides a significant source for information on Russian Orthodoxy in North America in the Interwar years as well as in the immediate aftermath of World War II. In addition, Konovalov's papers present a valuable record of the functioning and economic struggles of the Pokrov Skete in Alberta, Canada.

The Speeches and Writings file reflects the personal interests of Fr. Amvrosii, which included eschatological research as well as studies of holy fathers and church history. The Subject File materials relating to the history of the Russian Orthodox Church Outside Russia, including an almost complete collection of "Tserkovnyia viedomosti," the official ecclesiastical periodical of the Russian Orthodox Church Outside Russia during the Interwar years.

Detailed processing and preservation microfilming for these materials were made possible by a generous grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities and by matching funds from the Hoover Institution and the Holy Trinity Seminary. The grant also provides depositing a microfilm copy in the Hoover Institution Archives. The original materials remain in the Holy Trinity Seminary Archives as its property. A transfer table indicating corresponding box and reel numbers is appended to this register. Any views, findings, conclusions or recommendations expressed in these materials do not necessarily represent those of the National Endowment for the Humanities.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into five series: Biographical file, Correspondence, Speeches and writings, and Photographs

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Victor Andreevich Konovalov was born in St. Petersburg in 1890, joined the White Army during the Civil War in Russia in 1918, and was forced to evacuate to Constantinople in 1920. From 1921 to 1923 Konovalov was actively involved in the Russian Orthodox Church in Constantinople. He soon immigrated to Canada, where he became a self-proclaimed missionary. Konovalov subsequently became a Russian Orthodox monk and abbot of the Pokrov convent in Bluffton, Alberta, Canada.
Archimandrite Amvrosii (Konovalov) died in 1971 at Holy Trinity Monastery in Jordanville, N.Y.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes ecclesiastical documents, military record, will. Arranged alphabetically by physical form

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Cards and letters, arranged alphabetically by name of correspondent
